sections.summary: The text identifies the Scripture given to **Moses** as a guide and details the twofold decree of mischief for the **Children of Israel**, resulting in their twice-met punishment and the destruction of the **Temple** [214–215].

The Quran is established as the most upright **guidance**, while the text contrasts those seeking the **fleeting life** with those pursuing the **Hereafter**. It affirms that every soul is tied to its own **fate** and will be judged by its own **Book of Deeds** [215–216].

This section provides essential social and moral ordinances, commanding kindness to **parents** and the rights of the **needy**. It strictly prohibits **extravagance, infanticide, adultery, and murder**, while mandating the protection of **orphan property** and fair measurement in trade [216–217].

Allah refutes the attribution of partners or offspring to Him, declaring that the entire universe performs **Tasbih** (glorification) of its Lord. The text addresses skepticism regarding **Resurrection**, affirming that the Creator who originated humanity can easily restore it [217–218].

Believers are instructed to practice virtuous speech to avoid the discord sown by **Satan**. The narrative details the refusal of **Iblis** to prostrate to **Adam** and his vow to mislead humanity, though he is granted no **authority** over the sincere servants of Allah [218–219].

Allah highlights His control over the sea and the preservation of human life during **adversity**, rebuking human ingratitude. He affirms the inherent **honor** bestowed upon the **Children of Adam**, who have been favored over much of the created world [219–220].

Humanity will be summoned with their **leaders** on Judgment Day to face their records. Believers are commanded to perform **prayer** and the **night vigil (Tahajjud)**, while the text defines the Quran as a **healing** and addresses the mystery of the **Spirit (Ruh)** [220–221].

The text asserts the challenge of producing the like of the **Quran** and critiques those who demand physical **miracles** as a condition for faith. It clarifies that **messengers** are sent as humans to be accessible to mankind [221–222].

Divine **guidance** and misguidance are attributed to Allah’s will, with disbelievers destined to be gathered on their faces, **blind, deaf, and dumb**. This fate is a recompense for rejecting the signs of **Resurrection** and doubting divine omnipotence.

Historical reference is made to the **nine clear signs** granted to **Moses** and his confrontation with **Pharaoh**. The narrative concludes with the drowning of the oppressors and the settlement of the Israelites as a promise for the Hereafter [222–223].

The surah concludes by establishing the Quran as the **Truth** and describing the humility of the knowledgeable who fall in **prostration**. It commands the use of the **Most Beautiful Names** and praises Allah, who has no **partner** in His sovereignty.
